Award.AwardTitle: Consolidation of Visual Perceptual Learning During Sleep

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
A growing body of evidence suggests that sleep plays an important role in strengthening what is learned before sleep and making the learning persist for a long time. This is called consolidation. Although consolidation in sleep is a key function in learning, the detailed mechanism is not clear. In this project, Dr. Yuka Sasaki of the Massachusetts General Hospital aims to clarify consolidation in sleep by combining cutting-edge brain imaging technologies such as magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), electroencephalography (EEG), magnetoencephalography (MEG), and functional MRI (fMRI). Particularly, the focus of the project is on examining the mechanism for sleep consolidation of learning of a visual task (perceptual learning) that is known to be associated with changes in a highly localized region in the visual cerebral cortex. Researchers are measuring spatio-temporal activation changes in the localized region during the initial period of sleep (non-REM sleep) after training on the visual task. Brain activity with high spatial resolution is obtained using MRI along with high temporal resolution brain signals obtained with EEG and MEG. By combining these signals with both temporally and spatially high resolution, the detailed mechanisms of sleep consolidation are being clarified. How such brain activity changes during sleep is related to improvement in performance on the visual task (the amount of perceptual learning) is being examined. The results from this project will contribute to a deeper understanding of the mechanism of sleep consolidation of perceptual learning.

This project provides rare opportunities of training and educating undergraduate and graduate students. Students learn cutting-edge neuroimaging techniques, such as the use of multimodal combinations of EEG/MEG/MRI, as well as functional MRI technique applied to retinotopic mapping. They also learn the theoretical backgrounds of the techniques. In addition, students learn how to analyze behavioral data through psychophysical experiments. Moreover, understanding of the consolidation process of memory and learning during sleep can help to improve education, by informing us how what is learned can be more efficiently and firmly memorized. In addition, therapeutic methods can be developed to eliminate or weaken bad and undesirable memory and learned habits, including traumatic memories, smoking, and obsessive behaviors.

POR.DRECONTENT:
A growing body of evidence suggests that sleep plays an important role in strengthening what is learned before sleep and making the learning last for a long time. This is called consolidation during sleep. Although consolidation during sleep is a key process in learning and memory to be formed, the detailed neural mechanism is poorly understood. In this project, we aimed to clarify consolidation of learning in sleep by using a new technique that combines the cutting-edge brain imaging technologies such as magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), polysomnography (PSG), magnetoencephalogram (MEG), and functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) with funding by the National Science Foundation.

It is important to note that we used the new non-invasive multi-modal neuroimaging technique to measure the neural correlates involving consolidation during sleep in human subjects, because such technique would allow us to measure and evaluate detailed brain activation during sleep. Both EEG and MEG have a fine temporal resolution in the order of milliseconds but relatively poor spatial resolution. In contrast, MRI has a fine spatial resolution in the order of millimeters, but relatively coarse temporal resolution. In our study, we used a technique that combined temporal information of the brain from EEG and MEG, and spatial information of the brain from MRI to capture brain activation in the early visual cortex in the order of milliseconds and millimeters. This technique is ideal to investigate brain activation represented by spontaneous brain oscillations, which are characteristic features during sleep.

The specific question that we asked in this project was which spontaneous brain oscillations were particularly involved in the consolidation of visual perceptual learning during sleep. Particularly we controlled and modified the training amount in two different visual field quadrants and asked whether the modification in the spontaneous brain oscillations were associated with the differential learning amount.

The task we employed in our project was a texture discrimination task, which is a standard visual perceptual learning paradigm in the visual science, and one of learning that has been shown to be consolidated during sleep. Moreover, this task is known to have a trained location specificity in which learning is only pertain to the trained visual field. Previously, it has been shown that the improved performance of this task in a given trained visual field quadrant is associated with increased neural activation in the part of early visual cortex, which retinotopically corresponds to the trained visual field quadrant. Moreover, we have confirmed that the part of early visual cortex, which retinotopically corresponds to the trained visual field quadrant increased the neural activation during non-rapid eye movement (NREM) sleep in the first sleep cycle. Based on these pieces of evidence, we asked which spontaneous brain oscillations, which are originated from the early visual cortex are particularly involved in the consolidation of the texture discrimination task during NREM sleep.

We have found that the power of spontaneous brain oscillations with the sigma band was more increased in the cortical region that was trained more, in comparison to the cortical region that was trained less. This modification was specific to the sleep stage 2. These results suggest that the spontaneous brain oscillations in particular with sigma band are strongly involved in the consolidation of visual perceptual learning at least in the NREM sleep in the first sleep.
